# Task

Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Here is a function to wrap text to a specified width:

```julia
function wrap_string(text::AbstractString, text_width::Int=10)
    words = split(text)
    current_line = ""
    result = ""
    
    for word in words
        if length(current_line) + length(word) + 1 > text_width
            result *= current_line * "\n"
            current_line = word
        else
            current_line = current_line == "" ? word : current_line * " " * word 
        end
    end
    
    return result * current_line
end
```

It splits the input text into words, then iterates through the words, adding them to the current line. If adding the next word would exceed the text width, it starts a new line. Finally it returns the formatted string.

Here is an example:

```julia
text = "This is some sample text that will be wrapped to demonstrate the function."

print(wrap_string(text))
```


The default text width is 10, but it can be customized by passing a different `text_width` argument.
